title: Will Bahrain, Qatar, or the UAE return an ambassador to Iran before 18 October 2016?
possible_answers: Yes, after Saudi Arabia announces that its ambassador will return to Tehran

Qatar's emir has urged Gulf Arab countries and Iran to settle their disputes through "dialogue," in a telephone call with Iranian President Hassan Rohani, state media reported on September 13. The Qatar News Agency said Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani telephoned Rohani on the Muslim Eid al-Adha holiday on September 12 and "stressed that Gulf-Iran relations should be based on good neighborly relations and mutual respect."  "Any Gulf-Iran disputes should be settled through negotiations and dialogue," the emir said.
http://www.rferl.org/content/qatari-emir-urges-dialogue-between-iran-arab-nations-call-to-president-rohani/27985076.html Even though I think Qatar only may return its ambassador in the next 6 months, the question asks by 18 Oct. Not in that short a time frame.

The Gulf States and Iran are openly competing for influence in the Gulf and broader Middle East.  There are clear reasons why the Gulf States would NOT send Ambassadors to Iran from punishing Iran for intervening in the internal affairs of regional countries (Bahrain, Yemen) and accordingly not wanting to give any further legitimacy to Iran.  However, related to this, the Gulf States might want to have Ambassadors in Iran precisely to have a voice in Iran to avoid an escalation in conflict.   The last line of this piece from the Foreign Policy blog has me thinking, if proxy conflicts between Iran and Saudi Arabia are going to continue to be a fact of life in the Middle East (and they are), then it would behoove the Gulf States to re-establish diplomatic ties.  
http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/07/26/what-would-a-saudi-iran-war-look-like-dont-look-now-but-it-is-already-here-2/ UAE says Iran is dangerous:
http://www.thetower.org/3179-uae-ambassador-one-year-after-nuclear-framework-iran-is-dangerous-as-ever/
http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2016/04/05/Emirati-ambassador-says-Iran-has-worsened-since-deal.html But UAE is "leading import source" for Iran:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_leading_trade_partners UAE has a vested interest in having diplomatic representation in Iran.   I think it's unlikely that Saudi Arabia will send an Ambassador to Iran, but considering there are three other countries on this question AND that it only takes one of them to resolve it as a yes, I'll say it's three times as likely to resolve as a yes with one of them sending an Ambassador (I'm looking at you, UAE).
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
Compared to last month, increasing "NO" by 2% and reducing the other two options by 1% each. Earlier on I expected at least one ambassador to return, but not any more.
Can't see any significant improvement in such a short time frame

http://www.criticalthreats.org/iran-news-round-june-21-2016 " Senior Iranian officials encouraged protests against the government of Bahrain and warned that its treatment of a leading Shia cleric could prompt an armed insurrection in the country. "The Iranian Foreign Ministry and several parliamentarians praised resistance against Bahrain’s government after it revoked the citizenship of Ayatollah Isa Qassim, Bahrain’s leading Shia cleric. The IRGC also released a statement warning the Bahraini government that its actions will “inflame the torch of an Islamic revolution of Bahrain and the formation of uprisings against the despotic regime governing the country.” Parliament Speaker Ali Larijani encouraged “the repressed people who have been deprived of their basic rights to revolt” and called for Bahrain’s rulers to “learn from the fate of the Shah of Iran,” who was deposed in the 1979 Islamic Revolution. This rhetoric comes as reports indicate that localized protests have already begun in Bahrain. The decision to strip Ayatollah Isa Qassim of his citizenship appears to be part of a larger crackdown by the government against the country’s Shia majority after the largest Shia political group in the country, al Wefaq, was suspended by a Bahraini court last week. In 2011 Bahrain’s Shia community staged large-scale protests that were suppressed by security forces. Bahraini security officials have repeatedly blamed Iran for having a hand in the uprising.
~~~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Well, I'd say that it's a safe forecast that Bahrain won't be sending an ambassador to Iran anytime soon!  Also, I think that what Iran has done with Bahrain will further poison its relations with Qatar and UAE.
Adjusting to reflect a bit more independence on the part of Bahrain, Qatar and UAE; but increasing likelihood of No

The reinstatement of the Gulf ambassadors in Tehran is linked to Iran changing its policy in the region, a senior Kuwaiti official has said. “We look forward to the ambassadors of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) returning to their posts in Tehran,” Khalid Al Jarallah, the deputy foreign minister, said. “However, this matter is directly linked to Iran’s policy in the region and its commitment to the essential principles of the United Nations Charter with regards to the non-interference in the domestic affairs of other countries and the respect of their sovereignty,” Al Jarallah told the media on the sideline of a Ramadan banquet hosted by the Minister of Foreign Affairs Shaikh Sabah Khalid Al Hamad Al Sabah, Kuwaiti media reported on Wednesday.
http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/gulf-ambassadors-return-linked-to-iran-s-attitudes-1.1846547 That is quite a silly attitude to take, so clearly the proxy wars will continue.
Riyadh seeks military dominance in the region, and this has sparked concerns among other players.

Confirming previous forecast.  With hardliners in Iran in control and the KSA leadership situation (1 & below) a positive outcome here is unlikely.
https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/iran/2016-05-30/keeping-iran-and-saudi-arabia-war
"It is hardly a secret that real authority is shifting to Crown Prince Muhammad bin Nayef and his son, Deputy Crown Prince Muhammad bin Salman. But the power vacuum does help explain the bizarre and self-destructive nature of present-day Saudi foreign policy that suddenly shifted from cautious use of Saudi Arabia’s vast oil wealth to further its aims, while always keeping its options open, to a militarised and confrontational pursuit of foreign policy objectives.

Assuming the others follow SA, it would require some kind of change in policy from them, which I can't see happening before October. The Syria war is the big sticking point between SA and Iran and that doesn't look like it'll be resolved any time soon, at least not overwhelmingly in favour of Assad or any of the rebel factions. Hope for détente rests on some kind of peace talks beginning between Turkey/SA and Iran, leading to a reinstatement of ambassadors. But that could happen without diplomatic relations, and there's still the Yemen business to put a spanner in things.
Middle bucket down 20% to be closer to consensus.

Going up on "No." Reasons: 1. SA having some internal turmoil with the firing of the oil minister. They won't be ready to go out on a limb over anything Iran-related for the rest of the year, at least.   2. No winding down of Yemen war, which I expect to come first.  3. Iran says to skip Hajj, which is mid-Sept. So Iran not looking to make any major moves towards SA soon, either.

Adjusting for passage of time. There are no signs of a thaw in relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran, the latest indication being that no Irani pilgrims are expected in Mecca  for the Haj this year in September. Bahrain will not act independently of Saudi Arabia, but there's a slight chance that the UAE or Qatar may. I have been higher than the consensus because of the UAE's historical ties with Iran, but this is looking more and more unlikely now.
No sign of improving relations.  Iran reportedly not attending Hajj 2016.

Bahrain could react first by sending Iran ambassador back.
This could be linked to opening of American embassy in Iran.

A lot of issues need to be resolved for Saudi Arabia to send an ambassador back like the Houthis in Yemen, most of which are highly unlikely to reach a satisfactory point for Saudi Arabia before October of this year.  There is a tiny possibility that Qatar seeking to increase its diplomatic importance will send its ambassador back to Tehran. UAE has no incentive to send its ambassador back before the Saudis. Bahrain is probably thinking that they will need Saudi Arabia's aid with the Shia population in the future so will follow its lead in order to secure the good-will of Saudi Arabia.
Sunni-Shia mutual loathing is too well rooted.  I give 2% because the Saudis SHOULD propose to open an embassy and the Iranis SHOULD accept their proposal.

Increasing "No" by 50% and decreasing  the "Yes" options accordingly. After the fiasco in Doha, it seems very unlikely that the current regime in Saudi Arabia will return its Ambassador to Tehran within the next six months. Bahrain will not do so without Saudi consent, so can be ruled out. Qatar and UAE have sometimes acted independently of SA, but in this case they probably won't. The UAE still has diplomatic representation in Tehran, so it can continue essential business and won't feel the need to return its ambassador. Qatar has had it differences with SA in the past particularly over Egypt but against Iran it seems solidly on side. There is a slight possibility of some change as a result of goodwill around the Haj pilgrimage hosted by Saudi Arabia in September, so I'm leaving a little room for that.
Lowering middle bucket 10% on news Iran didn't send a representative to Doha.

Last time Saudi Arabia recalled its ambassador to Iran it took three years to return the ambassador,  so a quick return to normal relations between the two is unlikely. Qatar is the most likely to restore normal regulations as it has close economic ties with Iran, has maintained its presence in Iran and has historical tried to balance its relationships with Iran and Saudi Arabia and be independent. The qatari media has also reported favorably on improved relationships with Iran so it is possible that they will reestablish normal relationships with Iran once the immediate outcry had passed.

Suspect the Oct. 18 deadline is irrelevant: progress on other Yeman/Assad issues may be more important to the Saudis. The attached link indicates a reversal of direction in Saudi/Iranian relations is required. Not a likely outcome in the current environment.  Saudi's are also reported to have cut commercial ties and flights to Iran.  Until commercial ties and flights are restored first, it seems unlikely that the ambasadors will be returned to Iran.   Positive signs (removal of the ambassadors may be a Saudi negotiating tact):
--The UN Syria negotiations in Geneva (scheduled to start Mar 14) Could lead to the creation of a transitional government, and decisions regarding Assad's future.
--Houthi rebels from Yeman are reportedly in Saudi Arabia to discuss prisoner exchanges and de-escalation of Yemani violence. From: http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/01/allies-saudi-arabia-showdown-iran-160104130416688.html
Ghanbar Naderi, a journalist with Kayhan, a publication closely linked to Khamenei, said the breaking of diplomatic relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran was inevitable.
"It was going to happen today or tomorrow. This is a natural outcome of what has been going on for the past four or five years in Syria, Iraq and Yemen," he told Al Jazeera.

Increasing "No" from my starting 10% last month, and reducing the other two proportionately. I'm uncomfortable being so far from the consensus and will gradually approach it during the course of the next 8 months if there's no news. My current prediction is based on the Saudis in particular becoming less rigid, but this may not happen without a change in their government.

Bahrain, Qatar, and/or the UAE will very likely follow the Saudi lead, and I think given (1) proxy conflicts in the region; (2) Saudi regime insecurity; and (3) unlikely collaboration on cutbacks in oil production, Saudi-Iranian diplomatic relations are unlikely to be rekindled again soon.

Going up on No. Reasons: 1. Passage of time with no attempts made to resolve the situation, and no real harm to any of the participants for maintaining their positions. 2. Declaration on Hezbollah seems to have made things worse, not better. 3. @JP said: "Iran seems emboldened and willing to double-down. The nuclear deal is behind them, Sanctions for violations do not seem that impactful. Stir all of this into the pot and it seems that no ambassador will return before October." I agree.
It's in their best interest to keep both sides in balance, and show their independence.
Tensions will drop as Iran adopts anymore option posture after sanctions removed.
evil has been done in relation to the price of a barrel so Saudi Arabia and Iran are being competitors, and I see poor reasons for integration

If the reformists do well in the Iranian elections and Iran behaves well in terms of the nuclear agreement, then a return is likely. I think the reformists will do well and Iran will behave.

Do not see the Saudis and Iranians coming to any kind of agreement in the next 10 months that would lead to an ambassador returning and there is little chance those 3 allies send someone to Iran prior to the Saudis.

The Sunni-Shia proxy conflict continues to escalate and is forcing countries to consolidate their alliances and dig into harder positions.  The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) has now issued a travel ban for its citizens to avoid Lebanon due to increased risk from Hezbollah. According to this article, Lebanon is at the forefront of the proxy fight: http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/02/kuwait-joins-gulf-allies-banning-travel-lebanon-160224161730185.html At one point, I would have ventured to say that Qatar would return its ambassador first, since it seems they are oftentimes playing outside narrow roles. But, it seems tensions are now too high and the "proxy fight is on". Plus, the article again highlights the substantial conflict in Yemen. so, there are three major fronts: Syria, Lebanon, and Yemen. Iran seems emboldened and willing to double-down. The nuclear deal is behind them, Sanctions for violations do not seem that impactful. Stir all of this into the pot and it seems that no ambassador will return before October. A side note: Yemen seriously concerns me. Geographically, it abuts SA. If any anti-SA faction were to cement their position, this would create a very substantial threat/risk to SA and the many subsequent implications (oil, for one). Sometimes there are articles that suggest GCC will provide troops for a Syria mission, but it seems it might be a better strategic/tactical deployment to protect the flank (Yemen).
Affirming prior. Really haven't found much on this lately.

Lowering (YS) from 9 to 7.
Raising (NO) from 91 to 93. Following on my initial forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/129811), there really isn't any daylight between within the UAE/Saudi relationship. Feb 23: "Saudi and UAE ban citizens from travelling to Lebanon" --> http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/02/saudi-uae-ban-citizens-travelling-lebanon-160223154000581.html Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have urged their citizens to leave Lebanon or avoid travelling there after Riyadh halted $4bn in aid to Lebanese security forces in response to "hostile" positions linked to Lebanese Shia group Hezbollah.
[...]
On Friday, the United Arab Emirates announced "full support" of Saudi's review of its relations with Lebanon, blaming the country's "failure to condemn Iran's aggression" in the embassy incident. "The UAE fully supports the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's decision to halt its aid to the Lebanese army and security forces," said the UAE's foreign ministry statement, posted on state media on Tuesday. "At the same time [the UAE] calls upon Lebanon and its people to restore Lebanon to the Arab Nation where it belongs, away from the Iranian influences adopted by the so-called Hezbollah," the UAE statement added.

Edit: This should be 5% after SA, 58% before SA, and 37% No. I think Qatar will wait several months, but they will be the first to reinstate their ambassador. Like UAE they only recalled the ambassador, while Saudi Arabia and Bahrain cut diplomatic ties.  Qatar has relatively good relations with Iran: http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/02/qatar-balancing-act-saudi-arabia-iran-risk.html# Also, Qatar is the odd one out - Saudi Arabia recalled their ambassador to Qatar from 2002-2008, and Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and UAE recalled their ambassadors to Qatar for 8 months in 2014.  Some of the recent disagreements are summarized here: http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/06/world/middleeast/3-persian-gulf-states-pull-ambassadors-from-qatar.html?_r=0 and  The situation with Saudi Arabia and Bahrain, however, is still escalating.  They have banned Iranian ships from their waters (http://www.reuters.com/article/iran-shipping-saudi-idUSL8N15N37K), Saudi Arabia is conducting a trail of a group accused of spying for Iran (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-iran-security-idUSKCN0VV0GF) and Bahrain is accusing Iran of "internal interference" (http://www.rferl.org/content/iran-bahrain-to-counter-interference/27565345.html).
Mostly following Khalid on this one.  Likelihood of "No" will decrease if moderates do well in Iran elections.

Ukraine Warning Intelligence Update: Social Unrest Likely as Ukraine’s Ruling Coalition Breaks By Hugo Spaulding Key Takeaway: Ukraine’s post-revolution leadership faces an existential crisis on the second anniversary of the collapse of Russia’s client regime in Kyiv, which transpired on February 21, 2014. The pro-Western coalition lost its parliamentary majority at a moment of severe popular distrust of President Petro Poroshenko and Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk. Without sustained efforts to support reform and combat corruption, Poroshenko faces the prospect of mounting social unrest and the resurgence of Ukraine’s political old guard. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko’s party triggered the disintegration of the pro-Western four-party coalition by launching a failed vote of no confidence against Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk on February 16. Poroshenko called for Yatsenyuk’s resignation on the day of the vote after junior coalition parties announced their unwillingness to work with the prime minister, threatening to deadlock already stagnant efforts at economic and anti-corruption reform. The “Fatherland” party of former Prime Minister Yuliya Tymoshenko and the Western Ukraine-based “Self Help” party defected to the opposition in response to the failure of the no-confidence motion, which precludes another vote of no confidence until the next session of parliament begins in September. The withdrawal of the two junior parties deprives the “European Ukraine” coalition of its majority in parliament and takes it farther from the constitutional supermajority with which it began its mandate. The collapse of the coalition is likely to ensure the continued stagnation of reforms necessary to maintain vital financial support from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which signaled earlier this month that it would delay an assistance package worth $1.7 billion until the future of the cabinet became clear. Russia’s continued military operations in the southeastern Donbas region and economic pressure have also ensured that Ukraine’s pro-Western government remains frail. A protracted political struggle, worsening economic conditions, and the pro-reform elite and population’s hardening distrust of Ukraine’s leaders threaten to spiral into widespread social unrest.  Poroshenko may thus face a perfect storm on the anniversary of sniper attacks on protestors in the final days of the “Euromaidan” revolution. President Poroshenko called for Yatsenyuk’s resignation in response to mounting domestic and Western pressure to kick-start Ukraine’s stalled anti-corruption and reform efforts. The failed no-confidence motion follows the February 3 resignation of Lithuanian-born Economy Minister Aivaras Abromavicius, who blamed pervasive corruption in the central government and singled out Poroshenko allies for his departure. The resignation of Abromavicius prompted new scrutiny over the fate of the cabinet, which is divided between other foreign-born technocrats and coalition party officials. Yatsenyuk in particular has faced heavy criticism for protecting the interests of oligarchs at the expense of the reforms required to maintain IMF assistance and avoid bankruptcy. On the day of the failed no-confidence vote, Poroshenko also called for the resignation of ally Prosecutor General Viktor Shokin, widely accused of corruption. Poroshenko finally caved to long-standing pressure to dismiss Shokin following the February 15 resignation of reformist Deputy Prosecutor General Vitaly Kasko, who accused Shokin of blocking judicial reforms. Like Poroshenko’s decision to push out Shokin from the judiciary, the president’s support for the no-confidence motion against Yatsenyuk was likely an effort to deflect criticism for failing to combat corruption and promote reform. The manner in which the no-confidence motion failed raises doubts over the sincerity of Poroshenko’s intent to revise the political status quo, which is guided by oligarch consensus. The motion against the widely unpopular prime minister and his cabinet fell short of a parliamentary majority by 32 votes. Despite Poroshenko’s call for the resignation of the cabinet and the initiation of the motion by the president’s party, 39 MPs from his party were absent, abstained, or otherwise did not participate in the vote. The majority of the pro-Russian “Opposition Bloc,” the successor of the ousted Yanukovych regime’s “Party of Regions,” also walked out on the vote, depriving the no-confidence motion of as many as 33 votes. A total of 41 MPs from the two parties voted the same day to recognize the performance of the cabinet as unsatisfactory but stopped short of supporting the no-confidence motion. Mustafa Nayyem, a prominent reformist MP from Poroshenko’s party and an early supporter of the 2013-2014 “Euromaidan” revolution, accused the president of colluding with rival oligarchs who support the “Opposition Bloc” and Yatsenyuk to stage a failed no-confidence vote. If Poroshenko did intend to use the failed vote to defuse pressure to overhaul the cabinet and cast himself as a champion of reform, this gamble appears to have backfired. Neither the no-confidence motion nor the dismissal of Shokin from the judiciary resolved the underlying driver of the political crisis. The failed vote of no confidence appears to have instead exacerbated the public and reformist political elite’s mistrust of Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk. Poroshenko, Yatsenyuk, and Ukraine’s other pro-Western leaders will need to make sustained efforts to crack down on corruption and support reform in order to restore this faith. The resignation of Yatsenyuk and a cabinet reshuffle that introduces new technocratic ministers is likely a prerequisite needed to prevent deepening political gridlock from devolving into a new wave of social unrest. Ukraine’s latest political crisis may escalate in ways that place the survival of the current Western-backed government at risk. Several hundred protestors outside parliament called for Prime Minister Yatsenyuk’s resignation ahead of the failed no-confidence vote, an early warning of the potential for the political status quo to catalyze the population into demonstrations against the government. The demonstrators included supporters of the far-right “Freedom” party, which played a leading role in the August 31, 2015 riot that resulted in three killed and over 100 injured. More dangerously, former Prime Minister Yuliya Tymoshenko is poised to fuel the crisis to reassert herself as a significant powerbroker in Kyiv. Tymoshenko called for snap elections to be held as soon as possible during an early February visit to Washington, D.C., where she met with senior diplomats and congressional leaders. All other party leaders from the former five-party coalition have dismissed snap elections as only a course of last resort given their potential to trigger further instability. Tymoshenko, a historical opportunist with a mercurial relationship with the Kremlin, may find success at the ballots along with the pro-Russian “Opposition Bloc” in the vacuum created by popular dissatisfaction with Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk. A strengthened position in parliament for either Tymoshenko or the “Opposition Bloc” would further cement the already lingering heritage of oligarch-driven politics and restore levers of Russian influence in Kyiv. Ukraine’s political crisis coincides with escalating offensive operations by Russian-backed separatist forces along the front line in the southeast. Ukraine has come under increasing pressure from its Western backers to fulfill its political concessions tied to the February 2015 “Minsk II” ceasefire agreement despite the continued presence of forward-deployed Russian forces, weaponry, and cyclically escalating indirect fire attacks on Ukrainian positions. These concessions include the constitutional recognition of the “special status” of the occupied southeastern territory, a proposed amendment that lacks support outside Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk’s parties and sparked the August 31 riot. Populist leader Oleh Lyashko, who participated in the riot and defected to the opposition days later, offered to restore the coalition’s majority on February 18. Lyashko conditioned his return to the coalition, however, on the rejection of the “special status” clause in “Minsk II,” a move that Russia would likely meet with further escalation. Russia has deliberately made the fulfillment of the concessions politically untenable for Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk by preserving its offensive posture in southeastern Ukraine. By demanding the concessions in exchange for potential peace, Russia has also led the West to continue prodding Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk into supporting the measures that isolate them from their former coalition allies. Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk can prevent the political crisis from spilling onto the streets by showing genuine effort to move reforms forward and combat corruption, starting within their own circles. A cabinet reshuffle and a new coalition agreement will also be necessary but not likely sufficient to prevent reforms from stalling further. The preservation of Yatsenyuk as prime minister is likely to obstruct the return of Tymoshenko’s “Fatherland” and the “Self Help” party to the coalition unless they are given significantly expanded decision-making roles. Yatsenyuk would not likely need to resign to form a new coalition with Poroshenko’s party and Oleh Lyashko’s “Radical Party,” however, which have only demanded a cabinet reshuffle. Without the introduction of a truly technocratic cabinet out of Yatsenyuk’s control, such a coalition would nevertheless only harden public mistrust and political dividing lines until a new no-confidence measure can be launched in September. Despite the collapse of the coalition, a majority of MPs from all three former coalition parties worked with Yatsenyuk and Poroshenko’s parties to pass a key set of anti-corruption bills prescribed by the EU and IMF on February 18. The passage of this legislation offers some hope that Ukraine’s pro-Western leaders can overcome factional divides to support reform, however, they will need to sustain these efforts to earn back the trust of the population. Emotions will be high as Ukraine remembers the roughly 100 killed on Kyiv’s Independence Square (“Maidan Nezalezhnosti”) in the final days before Yanukovych’s ousting on February 21, 2014. If post-revolution leaders in Kyiv fail to escape the pull of political recidivism and make persistent efforts to reform, Ukrainians may likewise slide back into a revolutionary mindset to protect the legacy of “Euromaidan.”

In 2014, following Saudi Arabia's lead, Bahrain and the UAE withdrew their ambassadors from Qatar. Diplomatic relations were restored after 8 months. However, in that case, Qatar's offense (perceived support for the Muslim Brotherhood) was less serious than Iran's. Given the ongoing conflicts in Syria, Iraq, and Yemen, it is unlikely that relations will markedly improve in the next 8 months.  If relations are restored, it is that the GCC states with act as a group as they have done previously. However, there is a small chance that Qatar or the UAE will choose to act independently. They could both gain economically from ties with post-sanctions Iran. Of the group, Qatar has the most history or acting not in line with Saudi policy.

Of the countries listed, Qatar and the UAE seemed to have been the most open to relations with Iran, prior to the events following Saudi Arabia's execution of Nimr al-Nimr.  The UAE may be motivated by economic interests: as of 2012, before the sanctions were increased to their highest levels, the UAE was benefiting from its trade with Iran (http://www.turquoisepartners.com/iraninvestment/IIM-Jan12.pdf) and reports suggest they were looking forward to a renewed trade relationship (http://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/economy/boost-for-uae-iran-trade) Qatar foreign minister Khalid bin Mohammad Al Attiyah seemed pleased with the nuclear deal as well, saying the deal would "make the gulf region more secure" (http://www.alaan.tv/news/world-news/135784/qatar-iran-nuclear-deal-makes-region-more-secure-safe), Emir Tamim Bin Hamid Al-thani seemed interested in talking out their problems, as well (http://www.aljazeera.net/news/arabic/2015/9/28/%D8%A3%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%B1-%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%85%D8%B9-%D8%A5%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%84%D8%A7-%D9%85%D8%B0%D9%87%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%A9). Qatar has had more space between its interest and Saudi Arabia's in recent years, but the UAE seems to have the stronger incentive. Both, however, seem to value their relationships with their Arab neighbors much more than a possible relationship with Iran. Saudi Arabia is likely to be the deciding factor in this. It seems overwhelmingly likely they will continue to stay the course for the time being, but their leadership has been erratic, as one German spy agency noted (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-germany-warning-idUSKBN0TL1O020151202). Increased impulsivity could bring some to question the wisdom of following Saudi Arabia's lead.
Business opportunities will lure them back; Saudi us losing its influence.

The UAE has maintained diplomatic relations with Iran, only downgrading them by recalling its Ambassador, despite some of the other countries shutting down their embassies completely. It's very likely they'll be the first to send their Ambassador back, due to historically close ties (Iranians have been using Dubai's financial and trading hub to bypass sanctions, and going further back a significant portion of Dubai's population originated from Persia which is just a boat ride away). However, depending on what happens internally in Saudi Arabia, the Gulf Countries could coordinate their moves.  The UAE Ambassador may be the first to go back, but it's possible the Saudis will announce resumption of relations too. This reminds me of one of the IFPs from GJP's season 4 (the exact question is escaping me at the moment, but I remember having to read oodles from the Gulf Community Council). I've spent the last little bit looking at what I think are the keys to this IFP: 1) Are all three countries (Bahrain, Qatar, and the UAE) the *same?* That is, will they all act in lockstep? The answer to that, I think, is no. I closed the tab I was looking at (can't seem to find it again), but the impression I got was that Bahrain/Qatar's severing of ties was stronger message than the UAE's, so there might be some daylight for the UAE to act before the other two do, with regard to Iran. [EDIT -- found one --> http://www.khaleejtimes.com/nation/uae-recalls-its-ambassador-from-iran) 1b) Given the answer above, is there anything in the UAE/Iran relationship (or UAE/Saudi Relationship!) that one can point to that might indicate the UAE to side with Iran? Feb 3: "UAE Ambassador Al Otaiba: Iran ultimately a bigger threat than ISIS" --> http://www.washdiplomat.com/PouchArticle/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=411 And also... Feb 8: "UAE joins forces with Saudi Arabia, announces it is prepared to send troops to Syria" --> http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/02/08/uae-joins-forces-with-saudi-arabia-announces-it-is-prepared-to-send-troops-to-syria/ COMMENT: So just two quick articles, but it looks like my attempt to find daylight between the UAE/Saudi relationship (or a stronger UAE/Iran relationship) may not be mean much.
~~ There's also this, on the Bahrain/Saudi Relationship: Feb 9: "Saudi Arabia, Bahrain ban Iranian ships from ports - reports" --> http://www.reuters.com/article/iran-shipping-saudi-idUSL8N15N37K ~~ COMMENT: So, doesn't look like there's much room for Bahrain to move towards Iran (away from Saudi Arabia). Of course, at least in my limited experience of following events like this in the Middle East, these are the kinds of things that usually happen *suddenly* and without too much forewarning, so it's very possible that the US wakes up one day to headlines that Saudi Arabia has repaired relations with Iran (OR) one of these countries has returned its ambassador to Iran. For now, I'm going to stay relatively bearish (i.e. on the side of these three countries siding with Saudi Arabia in this conflict, at least for the next 6-8 months).
